We report the recent advances in heterogeneous catalysis with emphasis on electron configurations as driving forces of the catalytic reactions. Several descriptors, including size, shape, surface area, oxygen vacancies, hydrogen spill-over, and porosity have been extensively reported. Whereas most catalysis researchers avoid studying the effect of electronic property due to the difficulty in elucidating its effects in heterogeneously catalyzed reactions. Although this topic is extensively explored in homogeneous systems, there is no unifying paradigm for heterogeneous systems. We focus on the progress made and draw the reader's attention to the possibility that electron manipulation could be used to improve catalysis. Graphical abstract Unlabelled Image Keywords Catalytic descriptors Electron distribution Heterogeneous catalysts Surface mechanism 1 Introduction Modern society requires innovative catalysts for the sustainable synthesis of fuels and chemicals [1,2]. In the search for better catalyst materials, it is essential to identify the features that govern the activity and selectivity of a given catalyst for a certain process, i.e., the catalytic genome [3]. By establishing a descriptor-based strategy that permits linking surface features such as adsorption energies with the activity and selectivity of catalysts [4,5], significant progress has been made in transition-metal (TM) catalysis. Supported catalysts have been extensively researched in the field of heterogeneous catalysis due to their high catalytic activity and stability [6,7]. It has been discovered that controlling the particle sizes of metal nanoparticles can affect the properties and structural interactions of supported catalysts. Numerous works of literature have investigated how metal-support interactions (MSIs) can drastically influence the stability and activity of a catalyst. On the other hand, the effect of electronic properties in these metal-support interactions has been thoroughly described in terms of their arrangement and movements as descriptors that drive a large array of catalytic reactions [8–10]. The electronic or electron relay properties in MSIs, such as covalence O 2p- and d-band centers, oxygen vacancies (O2V), and eg occupancy, among others, as catalytic descriptors, result from a large number of redox reactions, detailing the electron dynamics and distribution in these nanomaterials. The impacts of electrons in these MSIs as catalytic descriptors in heterogeneously catalyzed processes have only been the subject of a limited number of investigations, despite significant research in homogeneous systems. A reliable descriptor for comparative material characterization across individual studies also necessitates the analysis of surface-specific reaction rates, which can reflect different reaction conditions, partial pressures, and catalyst properties such as varying surface area or TM abundance. To the best of our knowledge, a correlation between covalency and surface-specific reaction rates in substituted TM oxides does not exist. Efficient catalyst design is dependent on a comprehensive examination of the properties and specific effects resulting from the nature of each reaction. The optimal description can then be compared across various TM oxide processes, crystal shapes, and catalyst compositions. The descriptor-based strategy for designing new catalysts and materials relies on the existence of property correlations. Such correlations are the result of the underlying electronic structure of the surface or bulk system, and a classification of the property correlations is essential for the development of screening methods that quickly uncover new leads for catalysts or materials with superior capabilities. Extensive theoretical work has been devoted to the development of design concepts and descriptors for these important reactions, including the ORR and the OER, as well as the hydrogen evolution reaction (HER) and the CO2 reduction reaction (CO2RR), in sustainable energy systems [11]. Particularly well documented are the mechanistic investigations on variables such as shape, porosity, and H2/CO spillover, to name a few [12–14]. Due to the importance of this problem and our present research focus on electron-driven reactions in perovskite heterogeneous catalytic systems, we became interested in bridging this gap [15,16]. We are hopeful that this study will inspire and encourage additional research on electron manipulation and how it drives various catalytic reactions. This review is organized in accordance with the electronic driving force in heterogeneous and homogeneous catalytic systems, with an emphasis on heterogeneous systems, and describes the most significant achievements of electronic effects in metal-support interactions as catalytic descriptors. One of the most significant advancements in this field is the ability to modulate electron transfer through metal-support interactions. This has been achieved through the development of methods that control the distribution of oxygen vacancies (O2V) in metal oxide catalysts, as well as the creation of structured interfaces that can enhance electron transfer and improve catalytic performance. For example, research has shown that the presence of O2V can promote the oxygen reduction reaction (ORR) and oxygen evolution reaction (OER) in perovskite oxides, while the structure of the metal-support interface can greatly impact the stability and selectivity of the catalyst. Additionally, the electronic properties of metal-support interactions have been shown to play a critical role in the hydrogen evolution reaction (HER) and the CO2 reduction reaction (CO2RR), with the ability to modulate electron transfer through metal-support interactions proving to be essential for efficient catalyst design. [12–14] Despite these advances, there is still much to be learned about the role of electronic properties in metal-support interactions and their impact on catalytic performance. Further research is needed to fully understand the relationship between the electronic properties of metal-support interactions and their impact on various reactions, including the ORR, OER, HER, and CO2RR. This will require a combination of experimental and theoretical studies, which can provide insight into the fundamental mechanisms that drive these reactions and help guide the development of new and improved catalysts. One promising approach for advancing this field is the use of advanced materials characterization techniques, such as high-resolution imaging and spectroscopy, to directly probe the surface structure and electronic properties of metal-support interactions [5]. This can provide valuable information about the distribution of O2V and the arrangement of metal-support interactions, as well as their impact on the stability and selectivity of catalysts. Additionally, the use of advanced computational methods can help to uncover the underlying mechanisms that drive electron transfer and catalytic reactions, providing valuable information that can inform the development of new and improved catalysts [7]. With that, the electronic properties of metal-support interactions play a critical role in heterogeneous catalysis and represent a promising area for research and development. By better understanding these properties and their impact on catalytic performance, researchers can develop new and improved catalysts for the sustainable synthesis of fuels and chemicals. With continued research in this field, it is likely that significant advancements will be made in the coming years, which will have a positive impact on our ability to meet the demands of modern society. 2 Effects of electrons in catalytic systems: A brief introduction on homo- and heterogeneous catalytic reactions driven by electronic factors Both homogeneous and heterogeneous catalysts have found widespread use in industries. Ninety percent of industrial applications utilize heterogeneous catalysts, while only 10% utilize homogeneous catalysts. This is because it is challenging to separate the homogeneous catalyst at the end of the reaction. For the creation and optimization of efficient catalyst systems, it is vital to employ both experimental and theoretical approaches. In the field of catalysis, computational approaches based on first principles investigations of electronic structures have been the topic of extensive research due to the development of faster computing data, more efficient algorithms, and more precise methodologies over many years. Currently, computational investigations are utilized in most catalytic events to get an understanding of their electronic structures [17]. Calculations based on the fundamentals of Density Functional Theory (DFT) can be used to evaluate the investigation of electronic structures. Calculations of bond length, bond angle, and torsional angle of neat and/or encapsulated metal complexes have demonstrated that DFT is one of the most effective ways for gaining a better understanding of the change in structural or geometrical parameters [18,19]. In homogeneous catalysis, a metal cation stabilized by organic ligands is the most studied active site [20,21], Among the qualities that can be investigated are the coordination bond's basicity and acidity. These characteristics can be explained by analyzing the electronic and steric effects of ligands and the catalytic complex as a whole. The CO ligand is a ligand that binds to the metal center via the carbon atom (M-CO). The M-CO interaction is characterized by synergistic bonding, with CO functioning as a σ-donor and π-acceptor for d-orbitals in a metal complex [22]. IR spectroscopy has been used to explain the electronic effects of ligands; the greater the back donation, the stronger the M-CO bond and the lower the CO stretching frequency [22]. In addition, 13C NMR is employed to detect shielding and deshielding effects in terms of chemical shift due to the fluctuation of electronic surroundings. Furthermore, computational methods have been used in homogeneous catalysis to acquire a better understanding of the reaction mechanisms of catalytic organometallic processes where the generation of active sites or intermediates is difficult to explain experimentally [23,24]. By occupying low reaction coordinates, associative displacement or dissociative pathways generate highly active complexes with bulky and electron-rich ligands (Fig. 1 ). However, less significant ligands encourage bis-ligated pathways. Consequently, the dissociation of one of the ligands becomes more energetically favorable [24,25]. Besora et al., further explain this phenomenon in terms of bromomethane, CH3Br, and Pd0 phosphine complexes Pd(PR3) and Pd(PR3)2, which generate the equivalent PdII species (Pd(PR3)(CH3)Br and Pd(PR3)2(CH3)B)r. Both the concerted process and the SN2 mechanism contributed to the reaction (Fig. 2 ). The reaction was affected by the number of ligands on the metal cation, the type of phosphine, and the solvent. According to computational research, the mechanism for the monophosphine ligand changed from concerted to SN2 when THF was replaced with polar DMF. In contrast, the bigger PPh3 and PMe3 ligands favored the SN2 mechanism already present in the gas phase for bisphosphine ligands. It was found that the electronic nature of the ligand has a much bigger effect on the SN2 mechanism, with electron-deficient ligands making transition states less stable [26]. Understanding surface electronic structures makes it possible to understand the fundamentals of heterogeneous catalyst surface behaviour. DFT calculations are useful for evaluating catalytic trends on well-defined surfaces of transition metals [27]. Identification of the structure and composition of active surfaces, as well as how these elements affect the mechanisms underlying surface exchange reactions, remain difficult tasks [27]. Electronic structures can be analyzed using computational methods. Oxygen vacancies [28,29] and electron arrangements caused by lattice distortions [30,31], to name a few, are important parameters in the electronic structure analysis. The structure of these materials, such as perovskite-type oxides with ABO3 and the B-site occupied by transition metals containing d-orbitals, has been tuned for optimum catalytic efficiency using these parameters, which have been explored in heterogenous catalysis. A better explanation for the development of oxygen vacancies is the removal of O atoms from the surface lattice to participate in substrate conversion, leaving the surface with oxygen vacancies and reducing the oxidation state of transition metals. When neutral oxygen is removed from the surface lattice of LaMO3 (M = Mn3+, Fe3+), which has t2g 3eg 1 and t2g 3eg 2 electronic configurations, respectively, two electrons remain that are localized to the nearest vacancy. The electrons can then enter either the eg or t2g orbitals, depending on the respective energies of the crystal-field splitting energy and spin-pairing energy [32]. Due to the stability of the electron exchange, the electrons in Mn3+ dissociate into half-filled Mn2+, resulting in the favorable t2g 3eg 2 electron configuration. Oxygen mobility is determined by the strength of the M-O bond, the amount of oxygen vacancies present, and most crucially, the type of O sites present, all of which have a significant impact on the catalytic performance [33,34]. As a result of the size disparity between the cations in the catalytic metal oxide, the structure deviates from one symmetry to another, causing structural distortions that influence the electron arrangement of the original structure. The Goldschmidt tolerance factor is one method for identifying distortions in metal oxides, particularly in perovskite oxide. Octahedral tilting frequently occurs when the tolerance factor is equal to or larger than unity. An octahedral distortion occurs if the cation at the B-site is too small for octahedral symmetry [35]. Catalytic activity trends can be determined after the identification of lattice distortions that directly affect the electron arrangements. We also reported the interaction between the adsorbate (morin) and the metal d-orbitals at the catalyst surface in the same geometry and found that the interaction between the substrate and the catalyst surface, as well as the metal cation specific electrons, are essential for developing new descriptors for describing catalytic trends. Our results showed that catalytic activity was significantly influenced by the lowest adsorption energies on compressed electronic structures, such as those of LaCrO3 perovskite with an orthorhombic space group [15]. In addition, this catalyst demonstrated greater catalytic activity when compared to other catalysts that were studied (Fig. 3 ) [15]. 3 Electronic properties as the main driving force rather than surface area (comparative study) The solid catalysts in heterogeneously catalyzed reactions offer active sites for the adsorption of one or more of the reacting species. According to several reports, the catalytic process is mostly fueled by the nature of the active sites. The surface area, acid-base composition, roughness of the surface, and conductivity of the catalyst support are some of the documented properties of the solid catalysts that drive the surface reaction. The high surface area of the catalyst ensures the availability of adsorption sites for any species that reacts in surface area driven reactions. There are numerous techniques that have been used to increase surface area. These include doping the catalyst [36], changing the synthesis conditions, such as the calcination temperature, depositing active metals, and varying the size of the supporting metal catalyst [37]. The issue of surface area-driven reactions for transition metal-containing catalysts, particularly metal oxides, has been slightly deviating from the traditional view that the catalysts with the highest surface area invariably give the highest activity. Cobalt and nickel-doped bifunctional lanthanum-based perovskite oxides demonstrated that trends in the catalytic oxygen reduction/evolution reaction cannot be primarily inferred from surface area measurements. The surface area of the LaMnNiCoO3 (1:2:3) was the highest compared to the same catalysts but with different ratios, LaMnNiCoO3 (1:1:3 and 1:3:3), however, the catalytic activity difference was so high, that it could not be explained by the measurable difference in surface areas of the perovskite oxides [38]. We also showed that the surface areas of lanthanum-based perovskites, LaMO3 (M = Co, Fe, and Mn) do not conform to the high surface area-high activity narrative. LaCoO3 with the lowest surface area of 51 m2/g showed the highest activity in the hydrogenation of cinnamaldehyde compared to LaFeO3 and LaMnO3 with higher surface areas of 128 m2/g and 135 m2/g, respectively [16]. It is now clear that there are other parameters at play at the surface of a heterogeneous catalyst that govern catalytic activity aside from the surface area. In electrocatalysis and photocatalysis, electronic distributions, have been used to design novel catalysts (Fig. 4 ) [39–41]. However, there are just a few studies accessible in the literature that demonstrate the applicability of electron distribution for solid surface-driven catalysis. Recently, several investigations have focused on the dispersion of electrons to determine catalytic trends [15,42]. Mixed-metal oxides have served as the focal point of these studies and have offered valuable insights. Both theoretical and experimental techniques should be used to prove this. The impact of electronic structures on nitrogen heterogeneous catalysis on copper (Cu) and nickel (Ni) surfaces was reported by Wang and co-workers [42]. Their findings demonstrated that one of the descriptors that influenced the catalytic activity at the catalyst's surface was the bond strength and d-band center in transition metals. This was achieved using DFT calculations, X-ray emission, and absorption spectroscopy, which demonstrated that the strength of the binding between the adsorbate and the surface defined the trends in the catalytic activity during the synthesis of ammonia. In addition, the nitrogen-bond strength revealed higher catalytic activity for the synthesis of ammonia; this was explained by the fact that the interactions between an adsorbate and a metal surface can be linked to catalytic activity because these surfaces are home to active sites that are reactive [43]. In redox processes, Zheng et al. discovered that oxygen mobility in La-based perovskites (LaMO3, M = Sc-Cu) with first row transition metals has an electronic origin. Instead of the conventional surface area-related definition of catalytic activity, oxygen vacancy formation was determined to be the best descriptor for catalytic activity using DFT calculations [44]. The study reported that a wide range of variables affect what factors drive catalytic activity. As a result, in this instance, the conclusions reached were based on Jahn-Teller distortions of space groups of the various catalysts, which are brought on by a variety of factors but mostly by changes in the original structure's electron arrangement [44]. For use in SOFC cathodes, Lee et al. found an electronic structural descriptor for the ORR activity of electron-rich perovskites [45]. The oxygen (O) p-band center is the descriptor, which is unique to the active oxygen sublattice and is assessed in relation to Fermi energy. They established a correlation between this theoretical description and the overall ORR activity, allowing it to be used to forecast it. The area-specific resistance (which measures oxygen reduction reaction (ORR) activity) and oxygen exchange rates may both be predicted by the electronic structure descriptors, and they also correlate well with a variety of energies pertinent to the ORR. The migration of electrons to and from O2 and their interaction with the perovskite catalyst can be used to explain the effectiveness of these descriptors. They emphasize that the O p-band is a bulk property, making it possible to forecast ORR activity without having the current, extremely difficult-to-obtain precise knowledge of the perovskite surfaces. Even the bulk can be difficult to describe in perovskites with disordered cation and/or anion vacancy distributions, such as (Ba, Sr)(Co,Fe)O3-d. However, these disordered systems are still computationally tractable and can be investigated using specific qua-sirandom structures (SQS)23. We also demonstrate that the descriptor substantially corresponds with oxygen surface exchange rates, which are an important step in the ORR, and many energies crucial to the ORR (e.g., vacancy formation energies). All these findings show that the descriptor has control over the fundamental energetics underlying the ORR, which explains why it is so effective. The area specific resistance (ASR) of a number of SOFC perovskite-type cathode materials described in the literature is plotted against their first-principles calculated bulk O p-band center in Fig. 5 to illustrate the efficacy of the bulk O p-band descriptor (measured relative to the Fermi energy). The ASR is a characteristic resistance that describes the cathode ORR's contribution to the cell impedance and serves as a gauge for the catalyst's total ORR activity, which considers both surface and bulk kinetic processes. Because it can be influenced by numerous extrinsic factors related to microstructure and environment, the ASR is a flawed indicator of the intrinsic catalytic activity of bulk and surface materials. Unfortunately, for a wide variety of materials, there is no more accurate direct intrinsic measure of SOFC catalyst ORR capabilities. Using both experimental data and DFT calculations, Wang et al. reported that the eg orbital occupation served as an excellent descriptor for the catalytic activity of perovskite oxide-based peroxidase mimics [46]. The transitional metal oxide B-site was the center of their attention, and they generated the volcano plot depicted in Fig. 6 by connecting, among other things, orbital occupancies with the catalytic activity of nanozymes. Based on the total eg orbital occupied, the Ni-containing perovskite demonstrated greater catalytic activity [54]. Using La-based (LaMO3, M = Co, Cr, Fe, Ni, Cu, Mn, Zn) perovskites, we carried out a similar work and reported the effect of electron arrangement in the oxidation of morin. Our findings obtained from experimental and DFT calculations indicated that the dz 2 orbital occupation is the main descriptor that governs the catalytic activity rather than the entire eg orbital occupation and surface area of the catalysts. This suggests that the surface area cannot always be used as an isolated parameter and as a main descriptor for catalytic activity, as this proves that there are many other parameters that control the catalytic activity at the surface of the catalyst. 4 Effects of electrons on different types of heterogeneous catalytic reactions (solution phase, surface reactions, gas-phase) 4.1 Electronic effects in solution phase heterogeneous catalysis The theoretical analysis involving liquid-phase reactions is not straightforward to model. The challenge is associated with solvents reacting with reactants, thus influencing energetics and reaction mechanisms [47]. The development of new methods for solvation effects studies has been reported [48,49]. A study by Behtash et al. explained the solvent effects in the liquid phase hydrodeoxygenation of methyl propionate over the Pd(111) catalyst model [50]. To illustrate the hydrodeoxygenation of methyl propionate over a Pd catalyst model, they conducted a study based on first principles (DFT calculations). Their findings showed that decarbonylation pathways were discovered to be dominant over decarboxylation pathways in all reaction conditions. The dehydrogenated derivatives of propionate, however, are solvent stabilized in the presence of liquid water, which facilitates the decarboxylation pathway. It was discovered that the presence of a solvent alters the strength of adsorption for all classes of intermediates due to direct adsorbate-solvent interactions and indirect solvent-metal interactions that alter the metal's electronic structure and, in turn, alter the metal-adsorbate interaction. In terms of the activity of Pd(111), in the presence of liquid water, the activity was lower when compared to 1,4-dioxane as a solvent, and these observations are similar to the activity in the vapor phase. Lower activity in Pd(111) activity in liquid water can be explained by the fact that the Pd surface was more covered with water, making the propanoyl–methoxy type dissociations difficult to absorb on the active site. Propanoyl–methoxy type dissociations also become more rate-controlling in liquid water than the dehydrogenation steps that are most rate-controlling in 1,4-dioxane and in the vapor phase. In reactions like the oxidation of morin and the reduction of 4-ntrophenol utilizing dendrimer-encapsulated palladium nanoparticles that serve as nano-heterogeneous surfaces, the influence of electrons in the solution phase has been documented. To test the catalytic effectiveness of hydrogen peroxide as an oxidizing agent, morin was catalytically oxidized, utilizing dendrimers as templates for nanoparticles [51,52]. In another study, Yao et al., proposed that the eg occupancy is a suitable descriptor for the catalytic activity of a perovskite oxide-based peroxidase mimic (nanozyme) for the oxidation of 3,3 ′,5,5 ′-tetramethylbenzidine (TMB) with H2O2 [53]. In recent time, more than a few studies have demonstrated that for photo- and electrocatalysis, the eg occupancy of O 2p- and d-band centres of metals of the transition metal oxides (TMOs), serves as an effective activity descriptors to design efficient photo- and electrocatalysts, respectively [54,55]. However, little is known about the perovskite oxide-based activity descriptors. In order to demonstrate the direct link between the nanoenzyme activity and the eg occupancy, Xiaofeng et al. carried out a detailed study on the density function theory and experimental observations (Fig. 7 ). Because O2 species play a crucial role in these biomimetic catalytic reactions, the authors of this study predicted that the eg occupancy, as a potential descriptor (i.e., the d-electron population of the eg (σ*) antibonding orbitals associated with the transition metal sites), will control the nanoenzyme activity of perovskite transition metal oxides. In addition to being inexpensive and simple to prepare, the ABO3-type perovskite transition metal oxides with BO6 octahedral structure serve as a model system because of their diverse and controllable catalytic properties and structures, which may allow for the tuning of the eg occupancy by adjusting the ABO3 composition. They demonstrate that the primary factor controlling the nanoenzyme-like activity of ABO3-type perovskite transition metal oxides is their eg occupancy. This nanoenzyme's unique catalytic activity and eg occupancy are uniquely connected in a volcanic fashion. Thus, the perovskite transition metal oxides with an eg occupancy of 0 and 1.2 had the lowest and strongest peroxidase-like activities, respectively (Fig. 7). As shown by the mass activities of the perovskite transition metal oxides, the reliance of the volcano on the following eg occupancies confirms that the catalytic performance of the nanoenzyme is predominantly determined by the eg occupancy of the B cations (Fig. 7). 4.2 Electronic effects in heterogeneously catalyzed surface reactions Suntivich et al. demonstrated that the oxidation reduction reactions (ORR) over perovskite oxide-based catalysts for metal-air batteries and fuel cells are primarily influenced by eg occupancy of the (σ*)-orbital and the B-site transition metal–oxygen, which serves as a useful activity descriptor for the reactions [40]. Their findings also reflected the critical influences of eg occupancy and metal–oxygen on the competition between OH–/O2 2− displacement and hydroxyl ions regeneration on the surface of transition-metal ions as the rate-limiting steps for the oxygen reduction reaction, highlighting the importance of electronic properties in regulating oxide catalytic performance (Fig. 8 ). First, they identified the activity descriptor for the ORR by examining the relationship between the 3d-electron number of the B-site cation(s) and the oxygen reduction reaction activity under the hypothesis that the 3d-electron number of the eg occupation of the BO bond can affect the BO2 interaction strength (Scheme 1 ). The research focuses on the adaptability of the chemical-physical and catalytic properties of the perovskite catalyst, where A and B represent rare-earth and transition metal ions, respectively. These ions permit partial substitution to generate AA'BB'O3 (Fig. 8) for the experimental investigation of several oxides to establish a catalytic descriptor for oxygen reduction reactions. Catalytic active sites and interactions must be precisely identified at the catalytic surface. Numerous efforts have been made to link the electronic parameters of metal oxides with adsorbate binding energies and, subsequently, to correlate these with catalytic activity, because surface‑oxygen interactions occur. Recent research on both oxygen evolution reaction (OER) and oxygen evolution reduction (ORR) suggests that the eg orbital occupancy determines the catalytic activity at the surface of ABO3-type metal oxides having a metal cation with a 3d orbital at the B-site [56]. Suntivich et al., revealed that strong catalytic activity trends were seen for transition metal oxides with the eg orbital containing near to one electron [57]. In oxygen evolution reactions (OER), the trivalent Mn3+, Co3+, and Ni3+ containing metal oxides with the specific electron configurations t2g 3eg 1, t2g 5eg 1 and t2g 5eg 1 respectively, were found to be catalytically active. Even though, Mn3+ was less active than the other two metals [58]. Clearly, the amount of eg orbital electrons, is not the only factor examined for catalytic activity; Jahn-Teller distortions also play a crucial role in catalytic activity. In OER experiments, the tetragonally distorted spinel structure of Mn3O4, suffers Jahn-Teller distortion at the octahedral site, resulting in increased catalytic activity [56]. Mn3+ at the octahedral site of Mn3O4, is Jahn-Teller active; thus, the material is subjected to compression or elongation of the octahedral environment following d-orbital splitting. Consequently, if the Jahn-Teller distortion is suppressed, the eg orbital shrinks. This results in catalytic enhancement due to high binding in OER between intermediates and the surface of a heterogeneous catalyst in contact with the reaction solution mixture (Scheme 2 ) [56]. Recent research has forcused on the effect of HOMO electron distributions in the degenerate eg orbitals of first-row transition metals in La-based perovskites on the kinetics of morin oxidation to morin oxide [15]. This was accomplished by analyzing the metal‑oxygen (M-O) at the B-site of ABO3 perovskite, which served as a point of electronic structural modification that proved to regulate the surface binding energies (Scheme 3 ). Experiments in kinetics were undertaken to determine the optimal catalyst, LaCrO3 in our case, and to use it for concentration variation studies of morin and hydrogen peroxide. This was accomplished by defining the catalytic trends using a mix of kinetic studies and surface areas. Using DFT simulations, we determined that dz 2 orbital occupation plays an important role at the catalytic surface. In addition, we analyzed the effect of dz 2 orbital occupation and adsorption investigations, establishing a connection that described the Jahn-Teller distortion-induced surface catalytic activity trend. The lowest adsorption energies were observed at lower and higher dz 2 orbital occupations with more catalytic activity, in contrast to the higher adsorption energies observed at half-filled dz 2 orbital occupations. 4.3 Electronic effects in gas phase heterogeneous catalysis The effect of electrons on gas phase heterogeneous reactions has been studied. Utilizing DFT simulations, the examination of gas molecule adsorption on the perovskite surface yielded a comprehensive description of its gas sensing mechanism. CO oxidation is one of the processes explored utilizing the Au/TiO2 catalyst. Understanding the active sites and other parameters influencing the activity of Au/TiO2 catalysts in gas phase heterogeneous catalysis has been the subject of numerous studies. On the Au/TiO2 catalyst, O2 activation at the surface is regarded as the crucial step for CO oxidation because neither Au in its bulk form nor the TiO2 support can activate O2. Presently, the presence of AuNPs is regarded as the most important factor in O2 activation [59]. In numerous experiments, the Au-TiO2 contact was identified as the active site (s) [60,61]. According to Widmann et al., the quantity of active oxygen species on Au/TiO2 is linearly proportional to the number of perimeter sites at the Au-TiO2 interface, demonstrating that the interfaces play a dominating role in O2 activation [62]. Duan et al. described active sites, catalyst deactivation, and moisture effects in CO oxidation over Au/TiO2 catalysts [63]. The DFT simulations demonstrated that (i) the Au/TiO2 interface boundary can be easily oxidized; (ii) CO adsorption on oxidized Au leads to the creation of O-Au-CO species; and (iii) surface lattice oxygen serves as an active oxygen species on a TiO2 support, resulting in the generation of oxidized Au. Strong CO2 binds to the Otop/Ti5c site, forming carbonate that blocks access to the active site, and water can accelerate O2 dissociation and carbonate breakdown. They compared the results of their theoretical model to current experimental observations and found that they were largely consistent. In addition, DFT studies demonstrated that such perplexing aspects of catalytic CO oxidation over Au/TiO2 as active oxygen species, the process of catalyst deactivation and regeneration, and the effects of moisture play a crucial role in comprehending catalytic trends. At the interface, O2 is rapidly activated as the interface becomes oxidized. CO then creates O-Au-CO species by interacting with the oxidized interface. In addition to activating TiO2's lattice oxygen by receiving an electron from Ti3+ the oxidized interface also receives an electron from Ti3+. Fig. 9 (a-d) depicts the reaction processes of CO oxidation, which followed the Mars-van Krevelen (MvK) mechanism. The active O species is assigned to the surface lattice O in the MvK mechanism. They were able to determine the active oxygen species, the mechanism of catalyst degradation and regeneration, and the impacts of moisture in catalytic CO oxidation over Au/TiO2 based on DFT analysis (Fig. 10 ). 5 Mechanistic studies proving electronic properties to be driving force Mo et al., investigated the electronic effects of the Pt catalyst's surface and lattice oxygen (O2V) mobility in Pt/MnO2 that catalyzed the complete oxidation of toluene [64]. The enhanced activity was due to the metal-support contacts between the Pt nanoparticles and the support. Due to the role of these MSIs in Pt/MnO2, it was shown that the metal-support interactions in the supported Pt catalyst significantly enhanced the mobility of surface lattice oxygen and surface oxygen vacancies. In-situ DRIFTS research suggests that the electronic characteristics of the catalyst (O2V) may play a role in the oxidation of toluene. Lima et al. highlighted the d-band center as a catalytic descriptor for the oxygen reduction reaction in alkaline solution over a platinum catalyst [65]. Using the rotating disk electrode technique, they investigate the kinetics of the oxygen-reduction reaction on the surfaces of single crystals of Ir(111), Ag(111), Rh(111), Ru(0001), Au(111), and Pd(111) with platinum monolayers deposited on their surfaces, as well as on NPs of these metals dispersed on high-surface-area carbon. The link between the experimentally measured activities of various types of electrocatalysts and the metal d-band center energies showed a volcano-like dependency. In all cases, the electronic properties of the metal electrocatalyst, represented by the Ed value, were utilized to explicate the metal-dependent catalytic activities and demonstrate the relationship between their electronic properties and the oxygen reduction reaction kinetics. As illustrated in Fig. 11 , Pt/Pd(111), Pt/C, and Pt(111) topped the respective volcano plots. Due to the robustness of the metal d-band center descriptor, Pd demonstrated very high activity in alkaline conditions, indicating that it may be a viable substitute for Pt in fuel cells. Hydrogen spill-over is one of the mechanisms that explains the metal-support interaction on surfaces of heterogeneous catalytic systems. For this mechanism, H2 molecules undergo dissociative chemisorption upon interacting with precious metal catalysts prior to the reaction (Fig. 12a) [66,67]. DFT calculations provide valuable information for comprehending the hydrogen spill-over mechanism in metal oxides. Cooper et al., using DFT analysis, reported hydrogen spill-over on the MoO3 (010) surface in the presence of a platinum catalyst [68]. When the catalyst is dispersed as nanoclusters on the support material, the H2 molecules undergo dissociative chemisorption, and the Pt cluster surface is predominantly covered by hydrogen atoms. Then, spillover through the adsorption of H atoms from the Pt catalyst surface occurs. After migration from the Pt catalyst to the MoO3 (010) surface and protonation, the H atoms can form strong covalent bonds with the terminal oxygen atoms. Along the migration pathway, this indicated that the system transitions from repulsive OH interactions to attractive proton‑oxygen interactions [69]. Kuai et al. described the hydrogen spill-over phenomenon on ketone and aldehyde hydrogenation into alcohols over a Pd-based catalyst (Fig. 12b). On mesoporous TiO2, both Pd single atoms (Pd1) and Pd nanoparticles (PdNPs) were supported. 4-Methylacetophenone (MAP) was used as a substrate for hydrogenation with both Pd1/TiO2 and PdNPs/TiO2 as catalysts, and it was discovered that PdNPs/TiO2 exhibited a higher level of catalytic activity than Pd1/TiO2. This was attributed to the fact that bimetallic catalysts have synergistic effects between two cations, thus increasing their catalytic activity. The proposed mechanism depicts H2 molecules breaking apart over PdNPs into H atoms, followed by H atoms migrating over the TiO2 surface and being subsequently adsorbed on Pd1 sites. Therefore, Pd1 can serve as a reaction site for the hydrogenation of ketone and aldehyde [70]. 6 Electron distribution and dynamics in heterogeneous catalysis The Density Functional Theory (DFT) method aids in the investigation of the electronic structure related to the chemical characteristics of metal oxides. These include, among others, absorption energies, strain, and the d-band center [71,72]. Akhade et al., used DFT analysis to illustrate the effect of strain, d-band filling, and oxidation state on the d-band structure of the transition metal atoms in bulk cubic LaBO3 and SrBO3 perovskites. [72]. Their work highlighted the importance of the electrical structure and reactive surface features of cubic ABO3 perovskites. The strain effect was shown to create a shift in the d-band, hence altering the d-band properties used to establish a trend for the reactivity of metal oxides. They evaluated the influence of strain on the d-band filling of the transition metal at the B-site employing molecular orbitals in metal‑oxygen interactions. For example, LaTiO3 perovskite was discovered to have extremely low d-band filling and predominantly unfilled d-states. This was conclusive evidence of a hybridization gap between Ti (d-orbitals) and O atoms (sp-orbitals) [72]. To explain this, the Density of States (DOS) for Ti and O atoms was predicted to reveal distinct stresses in LaTiO3 perovskites. In Fig. 13 , it was depicted that the effect on strain in the electronic structure when it undergoes compression strain is that the band is bordered by d-orbitals occupying higher energies while the sp-orbitals occupy negative energies. In contrast, when the electronic structure undergoes tensile strain, the band is bordered by sp-orbitals occupying negative energies. Upon substitution at the B-site, the strain was shown to be proportional to the size of the B atom. The effect of strain on ABO3 systems can modify oxygen-vacancy formation observed in some perovskite-type oxides [73]. Also reported was the influence of strain on the surface electronic structure, and this study established a correlation between the strain effect on the surface of ABO3 and the surface d-band characteristics of the MnO2 terminated (001) LaMnO3 surface. The existence of Jahn-Teller distortions results in compressive strain, which widens the band, whereas tensile strain narrows it. A positive vacancy formation volume contributes to a decrease in vacancy formation energy under tensile strain, whereas an increase in elastic constants contributes to an increase in vacancy formation energy under compressive and tensile strains, and vice versa [74]. To assess the catalytic activity of graphene-based materials, the free energy of adsorption was used as a descriptor. As depicted in Fig. 14 (a,b), the overpotential of the ORR exhibits a volcano relationship with the adsorption energy of OH* (G(OH*)), whereas the overpotential of the OER exhibits a similar relationship with the difference between the adsorption energies of O* and OH* (G(O*) G(OH*)), which is consistent with previously reported findings [75]. Although the adsorption energies of OH* (G(OH*)) and O* (G(O*)) could explain the catalytic activities, they are not intrinsic descriptors of the structure; therefore, they do not indicate the role that doping, and defects play in defining the catalytic activities. To connect intrinsic doping and defect variables to catalytic activity, the out-of-plane pz orbital of active sites was regarded as an intrinsic descriptor because the out-of-plane pz orbital of carbon atoms in graphene is primarily responsible for the formation of the CO bond and that the pz electron occupation of active sites in graphene is responsible for the adsorption energy of OH*. The descriptor is the weighted projected density of states (PDOS) center of the pz orbital of carbon atoms on graphene (pz-center), which is defined as where pz is the PDOS for the pz orbital of the atoms at energy E and Ef is the Fermi level of the structure. The validation of the total sum of PDOS against the entire density of states implies that the total sum of PDOS equals the total DOS. To confirm the viability of the pz-center, we analyzed the link between the pz-center and the adsorption energy of OH* at various reaction sites of the heteroatom-doped defective graphene sheets (Fig. 15 ). As illustrated in Fig. 14c, there is an essentially linear link between the pz-center and G(OH*). Therefore, the pz-center could be a useful descriptor for describing the catalytic activity of these structures. The results provide a full understanding of the catalytic mechanism of graphene-based materials, and the descriptor enables the design of new ORR/OER catalysts based on graphene or other sp2 carbon materials. Sinthika et al. suggested a site-specific electronic descriptor based on Pz (pie) orbital occupancy and its contribution to electronic states at the Fermi level as a potential descriptor for the catalytic activity of graphene-based materials [76]. It was demonstrated that the Pz orbital occupancy can be employed as a straightforward yet potent descriptor for identifying the local surface reactivity of each active site in graphene-based catalysts. As depicted in Fig. 16 , they determined the atomic structure descriptors and developed a predictive model of the free energies of OH adsorption (GOH) at any site of nitrogen/boron-doped graphene. It was anticipated that their model, in conjunction with these structural and electronic characteristics, would aid in the design of the optimal sp2-based catalyst. We used adsorption energies in LaMO3 (M = Co, Cr, Fe, Ni, Mn, Cu, Zn) perovskites at the surface of metal d-orbitals to examine catalytic trends in our recent paper [15]. We illustrated distinct adsorption zones (Fig. 17 ) in which the strain effect was identified as one of the regulating variables of catalysis. The interaction between the adsorbate and metal d-orbitals plays a key role, and we predicted that an adsorbate interacts with the catalytic surface of a metal in the same geometry, but that the environment may change due to surface straining (Jahn Teller distortions). On compressed electronic structures, such as LaCrO3 with an orthorhombic space group and the lowest dz2 orbital occupation, the adsorption energies are the lowest. As demonstrated in Table 1 , the electronic structures with the highest dz2 orbital occupancy had the highest adsorption energies. Our findings are comparable to the observations of the strain effect made by Akhade et al., who discovered compressed electronic structures on unfilled d-orbitals; this is indeed proof of the Jahn-Teller distortions' effect on perovskite-type oxides [72]. 7 Complementation by computational chemistry Fig. 18 shows that the LaBO3 (B = Mn, Co, and Ni) bulk oxygen vacancy (Ebulk vac, Fig. 18a), (001) BO2 surface oxygen vacancy (Esurf vac, Fig. 18b), and (001) BO2 O-above-B-site adsorption energies (EO-B, Fig. 18b) are linearly linked with the bulk O p-band center descriptor. Due to the complexity of the perovskite electronic, magnetic, and defect structures, care must be taken in determining the descriptors, and improved electronic structure methods are still required to establish them more reliably; however, these descriptors can be calculated accurately and rapidly enough to be a practical tool for first principles-based design of optimal catalysts for catalytic applications such as SOFC cathodes [45]. Zhang D et al. suggested a universal descriptor based on the pz-orbital property of active sites on the host graphene lattice for the oxygen reduction and evolution reaction activities of multi-doped carbon bifunctional catalysts [75]. On graphene, crystal orbital Hamilton population analysis based on the LOBSTER code 18–20 was used to determine the differences between the adsorption mechanisms of edged C and graphitic C. In addition, a range of graphene structures doped with heteroatoms (including nitrogen, sulfur, and phosphorus) and structural defects (including Stone–Wales defects, mono-vacancy, and edges saturated with hydrogen atoms) were created to verify the viability of the descriptor. They demonstrated that this descriptor accurately predicts the catalytic activity of dual-doped or tri-doped graphene with varied imperfections. In heterogeneous catalysis, several computational methods have been applied to various catalytic reactions, as emphasized. Computational chemistry provides a key foundation for a better understanding of catalytic descriptors, thereby facilitating the development of new catalysts. Computational chemistry can, therefore, be used to augment experimental methods and offer all the information required to direct investigations. By virtue of this, we can tweak the metal oxides and conduct in-depth mechanistic research to produce catalytic descriptors that best explain the patterns in catalytic activity and are in good accord with experimental studies. The investigation of electronic structures resulting from first principles (DFT) computations offers a significant opportunity to use electronic features of heterogeneous catalysts as descriptors of their catalytic activity. This demonstrated that electronic characteristics are essential descriptors, paving the way for a comprehensive understanding of the nature of materials and the rationalization of catalytic events. 8 Limitations so far Electronic structure is enthralling, and heterogeneous catalytic applications have exploded in recent years. Consequently, the development of catalysts with enhanced activity, selectivity, and stability that are ideal for catalytic reactions must be able to endure the extreme conditions that are present during catalytic processes. The current challenge is to build catalysts with enhanced properties. For the design of successful new heterogeneous catalysts, a molecular-orbital knowledge of atoms is essential due to the intricacy of surface interactions. The electronic structure of d-orbitals in transition metal oxides is still unresolved, and experimental findings are inadequately comprehended. The electronic distribution over the d-orbitals in transition metal oxides can be determined by Hard X-ray Photoemission Spectroscopy (HAXPES). However, the interpretation of the spectra is limited by the surface sensitivity of the technique and the lack of theoretical understanding of the electronic structure of these catalyst materials. As a result, the use of electronic descriptors in the design of new heterogeneous catalysts is limited. However, the application of these descriptors is still in its early stages, and further research is needed to fully understand their potential. Also, theoretical approaches, such as DFT analysis, provide structural information; nevertheless, computational structural models cannot be utilized to postulate the active sites of the materials to correlate with the catalytic activity. To overcome the limitations of the existing methods, researchers have turned to using a combination of theoretical and experimental techniques. For example, DFT calculations can be used to predict the structural properties of the catalysts, while experimental techniques such as X-ray Absorption Spectroscopy (XAS) can be used to validate the predictions. In particular, XAS can provide insight into the local environment of transition metal atoms and the oxidation state of the catalysts. This information is crucial for understanding the catalytic activity of the materials. Additionally, researchers have also been exploring the use of in situ spectroscopic techniques to monitor the electronic structure of catalysts during reactions. This includes techniques such as X-ray Absorption Fine Structure (XAFS) and Resonant Inelastic X-ray Scattering (RIXS), which provide information on the changes in the electronic structure of the catalysts during the reaction. The use of these in situ techniques has been instrumental in advancing our understanding of the electronic structure of catalysts and its impact on catalytic activity. Despite the advances in the field, there are still many challenges that need to be addressed. For example, there is a lack of robust computational models that can accurately predict the electronic structure of catalysts. Additionally, there is a need for more in-depth studies of the relationships between the electronic structure and the catalytic activity of catalysts. To address these challenges, researchers are working on developing new theoretical models, as well as improving existing ones, to provide a more comprehensive understanding of the electronic structure of catalysts. The study of the electronic structure of catalysts is a rapidly growing field that is crucial for the design of new and improved catalysts. The combination of theoretical and experimental techniques is providing new insights into the relationships between the electronic structure and the catalytic activity of catalysts. However, there are still many challenges that need to be addressed, and further research is needed to fully understand the electronic structure of catalysts and its impact on their catalytic properties. 9 Future design of heterogeneous catalysts by manipulation of electronic properties In the future, experimental and computational methods can be integrated into the design of innovative catalysts to address issues in catalytic applications. Indeed, additional research is essential: ● Numerous computational methodologies and models exist, necessitating a greater knowledge of how the various first-principles approaches can influence predictions. ● The pursuit of scaling up processes, such as high-throughput screening of various catalysts and surfaces. ● Development of catalytic reaction pathways on surfaces and with various catalytic species. Certainly, if the aforementioned enhancements can be realized, the future holds great promise for a major breakthrough in the surface chemistry of heterogeneous catalytic systems. In particular, the electronic properties of catalytic species can be manipulated to increase their activity and selectivity for a desired reaction. For example, the manipulation of the electronic properties of metal catalysts can affect the rate of reaction and the selectivity of the desired product. Moreover, the design of electronic properties in metal-organic frameworks (MOFs) can also influence their catalytic behaviour. One of the key approaches for manipulating electronic properties is to understand the role of the metal-support interaction (MSI) in heterogeneous catalysts. MSI is the interaction between the metal catalyst and the support material, and it can strongly affect the electronic properties of the catalyst. For example, the interaction between the metal and support can alter the metal's electron distribution and affect its ability to bind with reactants. Thus, understanding the MSI and how it affects the electronic properties of the catalyst can lead to the development of novel catalytic materials with improved activity and selectivity. Another important aspect of future catalyst design is the use of advanced computational methods, such as density functional theory (DFT) and molecular dynamics (MD), to understand and predict the electronic and geometric properties of catalytic species. These methods can be used to model the behaviour of the catalyst in different environments and to study the effects of various parameters, such as temperature and pressure, on the catalyst's performance. Furthermore, high-throughput screening methods can be used to rapidly evaluate the performance of thousands of potential catalytic materials, enabling the rapid discovery of novel catalysts with improved performance. The future of heterogeneous catalyst design holds great promise and is expected to be driven by advances in computational methods and a deeper understanding of the electronic properties of catalytic species. The integration of experimental and computational methods, along with a greater understanding of MSI, will be essential for realizing a major breakthrough in the field of surface chemistry. 10 Conclusions/summary This review article featured current research on the role of surface electronic properties on heterogeneous catalytic processes. Computational chemistry has proven to be one of the most effective techniques for enhancing our understanding of the surface chemistry of electronic structures. The creation of novel catalytic descriptors facilitates the efficient design of catalysts appropriate for catalytic computational techniques such as density functional theory (DFT) and molecular dynamics (MD) simulations, which have been employed in the study of surface electronic properties and their influence on heterogeneous catalytic reactions. DFT has been successful in providing insights into the electronic structure of catalytic surfaces, including the interaction of catalytic species with the surface, adsorption and desorption processes, and the role of surface defects. MD simulations, on the other hand, have been used to study the dynamic behaviour of catalytic systems and the thermodynamics of catalytic reactions. One important aspect of catalytic reactions that has been explored in detail is the effect of surface electronic properties on the selectivity and activity of catalysts. Studies have shown that surface electronic properties, such as surface charge and surface dipole, play a crucial role in determining the selectivity and activity of catalysts. For example, a highly charged surface can enhance the adsorption of reactant species and increase the selectivity of the reaction. A surface dipole, on the other hand, can influence the orientation of reactant species on the surface, which in turn affects the reaction selectivity. Another important aspect of surface electronic properties that has been studied is the influence of surface defects on catalytic activity. Surface defects, such as vacancies, can alter the electronic structure of the catalytic surface, leading to changes in the adsorption and reaction kinetics. These changes can result in either increased or decreased catalytic activity, depending on the nature and position of the defects. The study of surface electronic properties and their role in heterogeneous catalytic reactions has also led to the development of new catalytic descriptors, which are essential in the design of efficient catalysts. These descriptors take into account various properties of the surface, including surface charge, dipole, and defect density, and provide a quantitative measure of the surface electrical structure. These descriptors can be used to optimize the catalytic performance of existing catalysts or to design new catalysts for specific applications. In conclusion, the study of surface electronic properties has been an important area of research in the field of heterogeneous catalysis. Computational techniques, such as DFT and MD simulations, have provided valuable insights into the surface chemistry of electronic structures and their role in catalytic reactions. The development of new catalytic descriptors has facilitated the design of efficient catalysts and led to a better understanding of the relationship between surface electronic structure and catalytic performance. coredata.dc:description: We report the recent advances in heterogeneous catalysis with emphasis on electron configurations as driving forces of the catalytic reactions. Several descriptors, including size, shape, surface area, oxygen vacancies, hydrogen spill-over, and porosity have been extensively reported. Whereas most catalysis researchers avoid studying the effect of electronic property due to the difficulty in elucidating its effects in heterogeneously catalyzed reactions. Although this topic is extensively explored in homogeneous systems, there is no unifying paradigm for heterogeneous systems. We focus on the progress made and draw the reader's attention to the possibility that electron manipulation could be used to improve catalysis.
